newsitem.title: USA: CNN-Oracle web site may rival PointCast.
newsitem.headline: CNN-Oracle web site may rival PointCast.

text.p: CNN and Oracle Corp on Wednesday said their customized news web site would be faster and more efficient than services that 'push' personalized news, because it will not clog up the Internet's global computer network.
That could pose a challenge to privately-held PointCast Inc, the leader in a sector which has been blamed for hogging network bandwidth and clogging up corporate networks.

Although CNN, a unit of Time Warner Inc, and Oracle said they do not intend for CNN Custom News to directly compete with PointCast -- where, they said, CNN is the primary news service -- they were clear that the site will provide a similar service without straining the network.

"(With CNN Custom News) The only thing that goes across that narrow band network is the information (a user) wants to see," said Scott Teissler, CNN's senior vice president for New Media Strategy and Infrastructure. "This is much more appropriate in a world where bandwidth is precious."

The free web site, unveiled at the Comdex technology show here, will customize news and information from the TV network and other sources for users who visit the site. Database searching and organization technology were supplied by Oracle.

PointCast 'pushes' personalized news to users PC's over the internet, and organizes it into channels that are picked by the consumer. Users must first download PointCast's software to use the free service.
In a press briefing at the event, CNN executive Mark Berstein poo-pooed the competitive comparison to PointCast.
"Our philosophy is to make the news available whenever the customer should want it, wherever they are," he said.
"Some customers like the PointCast system. That's why we are the premium news channel there. If they want a personalized news service from CNN, this is our offering."
"We are very happy with our PointCast relationship," he added.
Cupertino, Calif.-based PointCast, which recently hired its first chief executive officer, is reportedly gearing up for an initial public offering.
